newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures end quiet trade mixed.
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures end quiet trade mixed.

text.p: IMM currency futures ended mixed after a session of uneventful range-trade before more U.S. economic data Friday and a weekend Group of Seven confab.

Futures showed scant response late when French finance minister Jean Arthuis said that current foreign exchange rates were more in line with fundamentals and that this must be consolidated in a lasting way.

Nor did currencies budge on news that Federal Reserve policymakers at their December 17 meeting voted unanimously to keep policy unchanged but kept a tightening bias, saying rates were more likely to rise than fall in the future.
The Canadian dollar eroded during the afternoon, with brokers saying the U.S. dollar triggered buystops in the cash market near the futures equivalent level of $0.7433.

A floor broker said technically the contract also could fall further before resuming its longer-term move higher. He said if March Canadian dollar futures punch below the $0.7422 level, the contract could slip to $0.7414.
"It's a pretty bearish scenario," he said of the Canadian unit's nearterm outlook. "It's in a corrective mode downward."
The Swiss franc, meanwhile, garnered some additional support from talk of big cash buying against yen.

Swiss franc rose overseas after some independent Swiss economists said in a report compiled in January and issued at the University of Lausanne that it was possible the Swiss unit was near levels where it could be considered undervalued.
As expected, the Bank of England, the Bundesbank and the Swiss National Bank on Thursday left official rates steady.
Marks backed off on news that the German employment picture dimmed more in January, when pan-German joblessness rose a seasonally adjusted 160,000 versus December 1996.
Some said the figures would give the Bundesbank a compelling reason to weigh a move toward lower rates.

March yen recovered from a new contract low hit overnight at $0.008105 or 124.00 spot as traders waited to see whether Group of Seven indicates discomfort with the dollar's runup. "If they (G7) don't come up with some sort of stability pact, this yen is going to 125.00 pretty quickly," said the broker.
Friday's January U.S. jobs report is seen showing non-farm payrolls rose 237,000, with joblessness at 5.2 percent.

March yen rose $0.000004 to $0.008130, marks lost $0.0013 to $0.6072, Swiss fr. up $0.0008 at $0.7042,pound fell $0.0058 to $1.6332, Can dollar fell $0.0034 to $0.7428, Aussie dollar rose $0.0024 to $0.7646, Mex peso rose $0.000150 to $0.125775. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750/E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com))
